TEXT.English: [TAB]Land may refer to: The part of the Earth that is not covered by water. Terrestrial ecoregion, an ecoregion based on soil instead of water.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Water is a chemical substance with the chemical formula H2O. Its molecule contains one oxygen and two hydrogen atoms connected by covalent bonds. Water is a liquid at ambient conditions, but it often co-exists on Earth with its solid state, ice, and gaseous state (water vapor or steam). Water also exists in a liquid crystal state near hydrophilic surfaces.
TEXT.French: [TAB] Âîäà ÿâëÿåòñÿ õèìè÷åñêèì âåùåñòâîì ñ ôîðìóëîé H2O. Åå ìîëåêóëà ñîäåðæèò îäèí àòîì êèñëîðîäà è äâà àòîìà âîäîðîäà, ñâÿçàííûõ êîâàëåíòíûìè ñâÿçÿìè. Âîäà ÿâëÿåòñÿ æèäêîñòüþ ïðè íîðìàëüíûõ óñëîâèÿõ, íî îíà ÷àñòî ñóùåñòâóåò íà Çåìëå â åå òâåðäîì (ëåä) è ãàçîîáðàçíîì (íàñûùåííûé è íåíàñûùåííûé ïàð) ñîñòîÿíèè. Îíà òàêæå ñóùåñòâóåò â æèäêîêðèñòàëëè÷åñêîì ñîñòîÿíèè - âáëèçè ãèäðîôèëüíûõ ïîâåðõíîñòåé.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Wasser ist eine chemische Substanz mit der Formel H2O. Es enthält also Sauerstoff und Wasserstoff. Bei Raumtemperatur ist es flüssig, existiert aber auf der Erde auch oft in gefrorener Form als Eis oder Schnee oder in Gasform als Wasserdampf.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Lumbermills[COLOR_REVERT] are [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]no direct upgrades[COLOR_REVERT] of [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Lodges[\LINK] or [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERJACK_CAMP]Lumberjack Camps[\LINK]. They can be directly built in [LINK=FEATURE_FOREST]Forests[\LINK], [LINK=FEATURE_LIGHT_FOREST]Light Forests[\LINK], [LINK=FEATURE_FOREST_TUNDRA]Taiga[\LINK] and [LINK=FEATURE_JUNGLE]Jungle[\LINK] as well. The production of [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Lumber[\LINK] and [LINK=YIELD_VALUABLE_WOOD]Valuable Wood[\LINK] there is more increased as if a Lodge or Lumberjack Camp is built. However, a Lumbermill costs more gold than a Lumberjack Camp and needs more time to be errected.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]

TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sägemühlen[COLOR_REVERT] sind [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]kein direktes Upgrade[COLOR_REVERT] einer [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Holzfällerhütte[\LINK] oder eines [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERJACK_CAMP]Holzfäller Camps[\LINK]. TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ruins[COLOR_REVERT] are the remnants of a city or improvement that has been abandoned or destroyed. They do not serve any in-game function other than decoration.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ruins are the remains of human-made architecture: structures that were once complete, as time went by, have fallen into a state of partial or complete disrepair, due to lack of maintenance or deliberate acts of destruction. Disasters, war and depopulation are the most common root causes, with many structures becoming progressively derelict over time due to long-term weathering and scavenging.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Îïèñàíèå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ðóèíû[COLOR_REVERT] ÿâëÿþòñÿ îñòàòêàìè ãîðîäà èëè óëó÷øåíèÿ, êîòîðûå áûëè çàáðîøåíû èëè óíè÷òîæåíû. Îíè íå ñëóæàò êàêîé-ëèáî äðóãîé âíóòðèèãðîâîé ôóíêöèåé, êàê äåêîðàöèåé.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ñïðàâî÷íàÿ èíôîðìàöèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ðóèíû ÿâëÿþòñÿ îñòàòêàìè ÷åëîâå÷åñêîé àðõèòåêòóðû: ïîñòðîéêè, êîòîðûå áûëè îäíàæäû çàâåðøåíû, ñî âðåìåíåì ñòàëè âïàäàòü â ñîñòîÿíèå ÷àñòè÷íîé ëèáî ïîëíîé íåèñïðàâíîñòè, èç-çà îòñóòñòâèÿ îáñëóæèâàíèÿ èëè óìûøëåííûõ äåéñòâèé ðàçðóøåíèÿ. Áåäñòâèÿ, âîéíà è ñîêðàùåíèå ÷èñëåííîñòè íàñåëåíèÿ ÿâëÿþòñÿ íàèáîëåå ðàñïðîñòðàíåííûìè ïðè÷èíàìè, â ñâÿçè ñ ÷åì ìíîãèå çäàíèÿ ñòàíîâÿòñÿ ïîñòåïåííî çàáðîøåííûìè ñïóñòÿ âðåìÿ, âñëåäñòâèå - äëèòåëüíîå âûâåòðèâàíèå è âûìûâàíèå.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ruinen sind die Reste menschlicher Architektur: Strukturen, die einst vollständig waren, dann aber durch den Einfluss der Umwelt, wie Pflanzen, Regen oder Wind, über die Zeit zerfielen. Gründe für die Verwahrlosung können Kriege, Katastrophen Disasters, Krankheiten und vieles mehr gewesen sein.

TEXT.English: Ancient Ruins

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]In [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ancient Ruins[COLOR_REVERT] you can often find treasures, useful information or even units. Beware though: the natives regard them as sacred, and they may not approve of you looting the graves of their ancestors. Only [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]Seasoned Scouts[\LINK] are experienced enough to not invoke their ire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ruins are the remains of human-made architecture: structures that were once complete, as time went by, have fallen into a state of partial or complete disrepair, due to lack of maintenance or deliberate acts of destruction. Natural disaster, war and depopulation are the most common root causes, with many structures becoming progressively derelict over time due to long-term weathering and scavenging.

Òîëüêî [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]Çàêàëåííûå Ðàçâåä÷èêè[\LINK] äîñòàòî÷íî îïûòíû äëÿ òîãî, ÷òîáû íå âûçâàòü ãíåâ èíäåéöåâ.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ñïðàâî÷íàÿ èíôîðìàöèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ðóèíû ÿâëÿþòñÿ îñòàòêàìè ÷åëîâå÷åñêîé àðõèòåêòóðû: ïîñòðîéêè, êîòîðûå áûëè îäíàæäû çàâåðøåíû, ñî âðåìåíåì ñòàëè âïàäàòü â ñîñòîÿíèå ÷àñòè÷íîé ëèáî ïîëíîé íåèñïðàâíîñòè, èç-çà îòñóòñòâèÿ îáñëóæèâàíèÿ èëè óìûøëåííûõ äåéñòâèé ðàçðóøåíèÿ. TEXT.German: [TAB]Ruinen sind die Reste menschlicher Architektur: Strukturen, die einst vollständig waren, dann aber durch den Einfluss der Umwelt, wie Pflanzen, Regen oder Wind, über die Zeit zerfielen. Gründe für die Verwahrlosung können Kriege, Katastrophen Disasters, Krankheiten und vieles mehr gewesen sein. In diesen Ruinen können sich manchmal noch wertvolle Dinge befinden.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]In [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Burial Grounds[COLOR_REVERT] you can often find treasures, useful information or even units. Beware though: the natives regard them as sacred, and they may not approve of you looting the graves of their ancestors. Only [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]Seasoned Scouts[\LINK] are experienced enough to not invoke their ire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]A burial ground or cemetery is a spatially defined area where the remains of deceased people are buried or are otherwise interred. The term "cemetery" implies that the land is specifically designated as a burial ground. The intact or cremated remains of deceased people may be interred. The remains may be interred in a grave, commonly referred to as burial, or may be interred in a tomb, an "above-ground grave" (resembling a sarcophagus), a mausoleum, columbarium, or other edifice. In Western cultures, funeral ceremonies are often observed in cemeteries. These ceremonies or rites of passage differ according to cultural practices and religious beliefs. Modern cemeteries often include crematoria, and some grounds previously used for both, continue as crematoria as a principal use long after the interment areas have been filled.

Òåðìèí ''ïîãîñò'' îçíà÷àåò, ÷òî ýòà çåìëÿ ñïåöèàëüíî îòâåäåíà êàê è êëàäáèùå. Íåâðåäèìûå èëè êðåìèðîâàííûå îñòàíêè óìåðøèõ ëþäåé ìîãóò áûòü çàõîðîíåíû. Ýòè îñòàíêè ìîãóò áûòü ïîãðåáåíû â ìîãèëå, îáû÷íî êîòîðàÿ íàçûâàåòñÿ çàõîðîíåíèåì, èëè ìîãóò áûòü çàõîðîíåíû â ãðîáíèöå, ïîäîáíî ''íàäçåìíîé ìîãèëå'' (íàïîìèíàþùàÿ ñàðêîôàã), ìàâçîëåå, êîëóìáàðèè, ëèáî äðóãîì ñîîðóæåíèè. Â çàïàäíûõ êóëüòóðàõ ïîãðåáàëüíûå öåðåìîíèè ÷àñòî íàáëþäàþòñÿ íà êëàäáèùàõ. Ýòè öåðåìîíèè èëè ðèòóàëû ïðîùàíèÿ ðàçëè÷àþòñÿ ñîãëàñíî êóëüòóðíûì îáû÷àÿì è ðåëèãèîçíûì âåðàì. Ñîâðåìåííûå êëàäáèùà ÷àñòî âêëþ÷àþò êðåìàòîðèé è íåñêîëüêî ó÷àñòêîâ çåìëè, ðàíåå ïîëüçóþòñÿ è òåì è äðóãèì, ïîñëå òîãî êàê ïîãðåáàëüíàÿ òåððèòîðèÿ áûëà çàïîëíåíà, îáû÷íî ïðîäîëæàþò äîëãî èñïîëüçîâàòü êðåìàòîðèé.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Begräbnisstätte oder ein Friedhof sind Orte, an denen Verstorbene begraben werden. In manchen Kulturen war und ist es üblich den Toten reiche Grabbeigaben mitzugeben. Sie gelten in den meisten Kulturen als geheiligte Orte.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]A burial ground or cemetery is a spatially defined area where the remains of deceased people are buried or are otherwise interred. The term "cemetery" implies that the land is specifically designated as a burial ground. The intact or cremated remains of deceased people may be interred. The remains may be interred in a grave, commonly referred to as burial, or may be interred in a tomb, an "above-ground grave" (resembling a sarcophagus), a mausoleum, columbarium, or other edifice. In Western cultures, funeral ceremonies are often observed in cemeteries. These ceremonies or rites of passage differ according to cultural practices and religious beliefs. Modern cemeteries often include crematoria, and some grounds previously used for both, continue as crematoria as a principal use long after the interment areas have been filled.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]A burial ground or cemetery is a spatially defined area where the remains of deceased people are buried or are otherwise interred. The term "cemetery" implies that the land is specifically designated as a burial ground. The intact or cremated remains of deceased people may be interred. The remains may be interred in a grave, commonly referred to as burial, or may be interred in a tomb, an "above-ground grave" (resembling a sarcophagus), a mausoleum, columbarium, or other edifice. In Western cultures, funeral ceremonies are often observed in cemeteries. These ceremonies or rites of passage differ according to cultural practices and religious beliefs. Modern cemeteries often include crematoria, and some grounds previously used for both, continue as crematoria as a principal use long after the interment areas have been filled.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ship Wreckages[COLOR_REVERT] are scattered across the Ocean. Maps, gold and even survivors of the crew might be found among the wreckage.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]A shipwreck is the remains of a ship that has wrecked. Shipwrecks are found either beached (on land) or sunk (at the bottom of a body of water). Whatever the cause, a sunken ship or a wrecked ship is a physical example of the event: this explains why the two concepts are often overlapping in English. The United Nations estimates that there are more than 3 million shipwrecks on the ocean floor.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Îïèñàíèå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Îáëîìêè êîðàáëåé[COLOR_REVERT] ðàçáðîñàíû ïî âñåìó Îêåàíó. Îáëîìêè êîðàáëåé íàõîäÿò âûáðîøåííûìè íà áåðåã (íà çåìëþ) èëè ïîòîïëåííûìè (íà äíå êàêèõ-ëèáî âîä). Êàêàÿ áû íå áûëà ïðè÷èíà, çàòîíóâøèé êîðàáëü èëè êîðàáëü, ïîòåðïåâøèé êðóøåíèå, ÿâëÿþòñÿ ôèçè÷åñêèì ïðèìåðîì ýòîãî ñîáûòèÿ: ýòî îáúÿñíÿåò, ïî÷åìó ýòè äâà ïîíÿòèÿ ÿâëÿþòñÿ ÷àñòûì äóáëèðîâàíèåì äðóã äðóãà â àíãëèéñêîì ÿçûêå. Ïî ïðåäâàðèòåëüíûì ðàñ÷åòàì Îðãàíèçàöèè Îáúåäèíåííûõ Íàöèé íà îêåàíè÷åñêîì äíå ïîêîèòñÿ îêîëî 3 ìèëëèîíîâ îáëîìêîâ êîðàáëåé.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Unter einem Schiffswrack versteht man die überreste eines verunglückten Schiffes. Manchmal kann man darin noch wertvolle Dinge finden. Ist man schnell Genug am Ort des Unglücks, gelingt es vielleicht sogar überlebenede zu retten.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Farm ist ein Stück Land, dass verschiedenste Gebäude und Anbauflächen beinhalten kann, aber primär der Produktion von Nahrung dient. TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Plantage ist üblicherweise ein grösseres Anbaugebiet von Pflanzen für den Verkauf oder deren Weiterverarbeitung.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]A plantation is a large artificially established forest, farm or estate, where crops are grown for sale, often in distant markets rather than for local on-site consumption. The term plantation is informal and not precisely defined.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Quarries[COLOR_REVERT] can be built only on Peaks. They increase the production of [LINK=YIELD_STONE]Stone[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]A quarry is a type of open-pit mine from which rock or minerals are extracted. Quarries are generally used for extracting building materials, such as dimension stone, construction aggregate, riprap, sand, and gravel. They are often colocated with concrete and asphalt plants due to the requirement for large amounts of aggregate in those materials. The word quarry can include underground quarrying for stone, such as Bath stone.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pastures[COLOR_REVERT] can be built on unvegetated terrain that is either flat or hilly, and where [LINK=CONCEPT_CATTLE_OR_SHEEP_BREEDING]Livestock[\LINK] can be bred. The production of [LINK=YIELD_HORSES]Horses[\LINK], [LINK=YIELD_CATTLE]Cattle[\LINK] and [LINK=YIELD_SHEEP]Sheep[\LINK] is increased on those tiles.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Pasture is land with vegetation cover used for grazing of livestock as part of a farm, or in ranching or other unenclosed pastoral systems or used by wild animals for grazing or browsing. Prior to the advent of factory farming, pasture was the primary source of food for grazing animals such as cattle and horses. It is still used extensively, particularly in arid regions where pasture land is unsuitable for any other agricultural production. In more humid regions, pasture grazing is exploited extensively for free range and organic farming.

Â áîëåå âëàæíûõ ðåãèîíàõ ïàñòáèùíûé âûïàñ îáøèðîíî ïðèìåíÿþò äëÿ ñâîáîäíîãî âûãîíà è îðãàíè÷åñêîãî çåìëåäåëèÿ.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Als 'Weideland' bezeichnet man Flächen mit Vegetation, die der Viehzucht dienen. Oft gehören diese Flächen zu einer Farm oder einer Ranch. In vielen Fällen dient dazu Land, dass ansonsten für den Anbau von Nutzpflanzen nicht geeignet ist.

It is still used extensively, particularly in arid regions where pasture land is unsuitable for any other agricultural production. In more humid regions, pasture grazing is exploited extensively for free range and organic farming.

TEXT.English: A winery is a building or property that produces wine, or a business involved in the production of wine, such as a wine company. Some wine companies own many wineries. Besides wine making equipment, larger wineries may also feature warehouses, bottling lines, laboratories, and large expanses of tanks known as tank farms. The oldest winery in the world found to date is a 6,000 year old winery in the Areni region of Armenia, which is still a wine making region today.
TEXT.French: Âèíîäåëüíÿ - ýòî çäàíèå èëè ñîáñòâåííîñòü, êîòîðîå ïðîèçâîäèò âèíî, ëèáî êîììåð÷åñêàÿ äåÿòåëüíîñòü, âîâëå÷åííàÿ â ïðîèçâîäñòâî âèíà, òàêàÿ êàê âèííàÿ êîìïàíèÿ. Íåêîòîðûå âèííûå êîìïàíèè âëàäåþò ìíîãèìè âèíîäåëüíÿìè. Ïîìèìî âèíà ñîçäàþò îáîðóäîâàíèå, êðóïíåéøèå âèíîäåëüíè ìîãóò òàêæå ñîäåðæàòü ñêëàäû ãîòîâîé ïðîäóêöèè, ëèíèè ðàçëèâà, ëàáîðàòîðèè, à òàêæå êðóïíûå ïðîñòðàíñòâåííûå ðåçåðâóàðû èçâåñòíûå êàê ðåçåðâóàðíûå ïàðêè. Ñòàðåéøàÿ â ìèðå âèíîäåëüíÿ, îáíàðóæåííàÿ â Àðìåíèè â ðàéîíå ñåëà Àðåíè, èìååò âîçðàñò 6,000 ëåò, äàííûé ðåãèîí äåëàåò âèíî è â íàøå âðåìÿ.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Weinberg oder ein Weinanbaugebiet ist ein Areal das dem Weinanbau gewidmet ist. Meist wurden dazu sonnige Hanglagen genutzt. Die ältesten Weinanbaugebiete, die man je fand lagen in Armenien und sind fast 6000 Jahre alt.

The oldest winery in the world found to date is a 6,000 year old winery in the Areni region of Armenia, which is still a wine making region today.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Forts[COLOR_REVERT] only work if a [LINK=CONCEPT_MILITARY_UNITS]Military Unit[\LINK] is stationed inside. To do this, [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Fortify[COLOR_REVERT] a military unit on the plot where the Fort is located.[NEWLINE]For more information on working Forts, see [LINK=CONCEPT_FORTS]Forts[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Fortifications are military constructions and buildings designed for defence in warfare and military bases. Humans have constructed defensive works for many thousands of years, in a variety of increasingly complex designs. The term is derived from the Latin fortis (strong) and facere (to make).

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Monasteries[COLOR_REVERT] only work once they are inhabited by monks. To do this, a colonist with the [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]Missionary[\LINK] profession needs to be fortified on the plot with the Monastery. Employing [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]Jesuit Missionaries[\LINK] or [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY_PROT]Evangelists[\LINK] increase the effectiveness of the Monastery.[NEWLINE]For more information on working Monasteries, see [LINK=CONCEPT_MONASTERIES]Monasteries[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Monastery denotes the building, or complex of buildings, comprising the domestic quarters and workplace(s) of monastics, whether monks or nuns, and whether living in community or alone (hermits). The monastery generally includes a place reserved for prayer which may be a chapel, church or temple, and may also serve as an oratory. A monastery complex typically comprises a number of buildings which include a church, dormitory, cloister, refectory, library, balneary and infirmary. Depending on the location, the monastic order and the occupation of its inhabitants, the complex may also include a wide range of buildings that facilitate self-sufficiency and service to the community. These may include a hospice, a school and a range of agricultural and manufacturing buildings such as a barn, a forge or a brewery.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Îïèñàíèå:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ìîíàñòûðè[COLOR_REVERT] ðàáîòàþò òîëüêî òîãäà, êîãäà îíè íàñåëåíû ìîíàõàìè. Äëÿ òîãî, ÷òîáû ñäåëàòü ýòî, êîëîíèñò ïðîôåññèè [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]Ìèññèîíåð[\LINK] äîëæåí áûòü óêðåïëåí íà äàííîé êëåòêå ñ ýòèì Ìîíàñòûðåì. Èñïîëüçîâàíèå [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]Èåçóèòñêèõ Ìèññèîíåðîâ[\LINK] èëè [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY_PROT]Åâàíãåëèñòîâ[\LINK] óâåëè÷èâàåò ýôôåêòèâíîñòü äàííîãî Ìîíàñòûðÿ.[NEWLINE] Äëÿ áîëåå ïîäðîáíîé èíôîðìàöèè î ðàáîòå Ìîíàñòûðåé, ñìîòðèòå ðàçäåë [LINK=CONCEPT_MONASTERIES]Ìîíàñòûðè[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ñïðàâî÷íàÿ èíôîðìàöèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1] Ìîíàñòûðü îáîçíà÷àåò çäàíèå, ëèáî êîìïëåêñ çäàíèé, âêëþ÷àþùèõ áûòîâûå ïîìåùåíèÿ è ðàáî÷åå ìåñòî(-à) ìîíàøåñòâóþùèõ, èëè ìîíàõîâ ëèáî ìîíàõèíü, æèâóùèõ â îáùèíå èëè â îäèíî÷åñòâå (îòøåëüíèêè). Ìîíàñòûðü îáû÷íî èìååò ìåñòî, ïðåäíàçíà÷åííîå äëÿ ìîëèòâû, êîòîðûì ìîæåò áûòü ÷àñîâíÿ, öåðêîâü èëè õðàì, à òàêæå ìîæåò ñëóæèòü â êà÷åñòâå îðàòîðèÿ. Ìîíàñòûðñêèé êîìïëåêñ îáû÷íî èìååò â ñâîåì ñîñòàâå ðÿä çäàíèé, êîòîðûìè ÿâëÿþòñÿ: öåðêîâü, äîðìèòîðèé, êëóàòð , òðàïåçíàÿ, áèáëèîòåêà, áàíÿ è áîëüíèöà. Â çàâèñèìîñòè îò ìåñòîïîëîæåíèÿ, ìîíàøåñêîãî îðäåíà è âèäà äåÿòåëüíîñòè åãî æèòåëåé, ýòîò êîìïëåêñ ìîæåò òàêæå âêëþ÷àòü øèðîêèé ðÿä çäàíèé, êîòîðûå ñïîñîáñòâóþò ñàìîîáåñïå÷åííîñòè è îáñëóæèâàþò äàííóþ îáùèíó. Îíè ìîãóò âêëþ÷àòü áîãàäåëüíþ, øêîëó è ðÿä ñåëüñêîõîçÿéñòâåííûõ è ïðîèçâîäñòâåííûõ çäàíèé, òàêèõ êàê ñàðàé, êóçíèöà ëèáî ïèâîâàðíÿ.
TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ein [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Kloster[COLOR_REVERT] ist nur aktiv, wenn Mönche darin leben. Dafür muss ein Kolonist im Beruf [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]Missionar[\LINK] im Kloster befestigt werden. Wird ein [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]Jesuiten Missionar[\LINK] ode einr [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY_PROT]Evangelist[\LINK] eingesetzt, erhöht sich die Effektivität des Klosters.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Für weitere Informationen siehe [LINK=CONCEPT_MONASTERIES]Klöster[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Der Begriff 'Kloster' steht für ein Gebäude oder einen Komplex mehrerer Gebäude, welches üblicherweise von Mönchen oder Nonnen bewohnt wird. Ein Kloster beinhaltet üblicherweise Gebetsstellen, wie eine Kapelle, eine Kirche oder einen Tempel, aber auch Räume oder Gebäude für den Alltag und die Selbstversorgung, wie einen Schlafsaal, Speisesaal, Werkstellen, Scheunen, Schmieden und manchmal Brauereien. In manchen größeren Klöstern findet man auch Büchereien, Schulen oder Krankenhäuser, die dann auch oft den umliegenden Gemeinden Dienste anbieten.

A monastery complex typically comprises a number of buildings which include a church, dormitory, cloister, refectory, library, balneary and infirmary. Depending on the location, the monastic order and the occupation of its inhabitants, the complex may also include a wide range of buildings that facilitate self-sufficiency and service to the community. These may include a hospice, a school and a range of agricultural and manufacturing buildings such as a barn, a forge or a brewery.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Grasslands are areas where the vegetation is dominated by grasses (Poaceae) and other herbaceous (non-woody) plants (forbs). However, sedge (Cyperaceae) and rush (Juncaceae) families can also be found. Grasslands occur naturally on all continents except Antarctica. In temperate latitudes, such as northwest Europe and the Great Plains and California in North America, native grasslands are dominated by perennial bunch grass species, whereas in warmer climates annual species form a greater component of the vegetation.

Îäíàêî, îñîêîâûå (ëàò.Cyperaceae) è ñèòíèêîâûå (ëàò.Juncaceae) ñåìåéñòâà ìîãóò áûòü òàêæå îáíàðóæåíû. Åñòåñòâåííî ëóãà èìåþò ìåñòî íà âñåõ êîíòèíåíòàõ çà èñêëþ÷åíèåì Àíòàðêòèäû. TEXT.English: [TAB]A desert is a landscape or region that receives an extremely low amount of precipitation, less than enough to support growth of most plants. Deserts are defined as areas with an average annual precipitation of less than 250 millimetres (10 in) per year, or as areas where more water is lost by evapotranspiration than falls as precipitation. In the K0ppen climate classification system, deserts are classed as BWh (hot desert) or BWk (temperate desert). In the Thornthwaite climate classification system, deserts would be classified as arid megathermal climates.

Ïóñòûíè îïðåäåëÿþòñÿ êàê îáëàñòè ñ ñðåäíåãîäîâûì êîëè÷åñòâîì îñàäêîâ ìåíåå ÷åì 250 ìèëëèìåòðîâ (10 äþéìîâ) â ãîä, ëèáî êàê îáëàñòè, ãäå ñóììàðíîå èñïàðåíèå âîäû áîëüøå, ÷åì âûïàäåíèå îñàäêîâ. TEXT.English: [TAB]In physical geography, tundra is a biome where the tree growth is hindered by low temperatures and short growing seasons. The term tundra comes through Russian from the Kildin Sami word tundâr "uplands," "treeless mountain tract." There are three types of tundra: Arctic tundra, alpine tundra, and Antarctic tundra. In tundra, the vegetation is composed of dwarf shrubs, sedges and grasses, mosses, and lichens. Scattered trees grow in some tundra. The ecotone (or ecological boundary region) between the tundra and the forest is known as the tree line or timberline.

Òåðìèí ''òóíäðà'' ïðîèñõîäèò îò Ðóññêîÿçû÷íîãî Êèëüäèí-ñààìñêîãî ñëîâà ''òóíòóðè''-''âîçâûøåííîñòè'', ''âûñîêàÿ áåçëåñíàÿ ãîðà''. Ñóùåñòâóåò òðè òèïà òóíäð: àðêòè÷åñêàÿ, àëüïèéñêàÿ è àíòàðêòè÷åñêàÿ. Ýêîòîí (ýêîëîãè÷åñêèé ïîãðàíè÷íûé ðàéîí) ìåæäó òóíäðîé è ëåñîì èçâåñòåí êàê ëåñîòóíäðà èëè ãðàíèöà ðàñïðîñòðàíåíèÿ ëåñà .

TEXT.English: [TAB]A hill is a landform that extends above the surrounding terrain. Hills often have a distinct summit, although in areas with scarp/dip topography a hill may refer to a particular section of flat terrain without a massive summit (e.g. Box Hill).

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ice is water frozen into the solid state. Usually ice is the phase known as ice Ih, which is the most abundant of the varying solid phases on the Earth's surface. It can appear transparent or opaque bluish-white color, depending on the presence of impurities or air inclusions. The addition of other materials such as soil may further alter the appearance.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The coastline is where the land meets the sea or ocean. A precise line that can be called a coastline cannot be determined due to the dynamic nature of tides. The term "coastal zone" can be used instead, which is a spatial zone where interaction of the sea and land processes occurs. Both the terms coast and coastal are often used to describe a geographic location or region; for example, New Zealand's West Coast, or the East and West Coasts of the United States.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Áåðåãîâàÿ ëèíèÿ - ýòî ìåñòî, ãäå ñóøà âñòðå÷àåòñÿ ñ ìîðåì èëè îêåàíîì. Äàííûé òåðìèí ''ïðèáðåæíàÿ çîíà'' ìîæåò áûòü èñïîëüçîâàí âìåñòî ''áåðåãîâîé ëèíèè'', êîòîðûé îçíà÷àåò ïðîñòðàíñòâåííóþ çîíó, ãäå èìååò ìåñòî âçàèìîäåéñòâèå äðóã íà äðóãà ìîðñêèõ è çåìíûõ ïðîöåññîâ. TEXT.English: [TAB]An ocean is a major body of saline water, and a principal component of the hydrosphere. Approximately 71% of the Earth's surface (3.6 x 10 8 km 2) is covered by ocean, a continuous body of water that is customarily divided into several principal oceans and smaller seas.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Îêåàí ÿâëÿåòñÿ êðóïíîé ÷àñòüþ ñîëåíûõ âîä, à òàêæå îñíîâíûì êîìïîíåíòîì ãèäðîñôåðû. Ïðèìåðíî 71% çåìíîé ïîâåðõíîñòè (3.6 x 10 8 km 2) ïîêðûò îêåàíîì, ñïëîøíàÿ ÷àñòü âîä, êîòîðàÿ îáû÷íî ðàçäåëåíà íà íåñêîëüêî îñíîâíûõ îêåàíîâ è ìåíåå êðóïíûõ ìîðåé.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Als Ozean bezeichnet man einen grosse Wasserfläche mit Salzwasser. Ungefähr 71% ist mit Ozeanen bedeckt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A marsh is a type of wetland that is dominated by herbaceous rather than woody plant species. Marshes can often be found at the edges of lakes and streams, where they form a transition between the aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. They are often dominated by grasses, rushes or reeds. If woody plants are present they tend to be low-growing shrubs. This form of vegetation is what differentiates marshes from other types of wetland such as swamps, which are dominated by trees, and bogs, which are wetlands that have accumulated deposits of acidic peat.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Ìàðøè (îò íåì. Marsch, Marschland) - êàòåãîðèÿ âîäíî-áîëîòíûõ óãîäèé, ïåðèîäè÷åñêè çàòîïëÿåìàÿ âîäàìè áëèçëåæàùåãî âîäîåìà, õàðàêòåðèçóþùàÿñÿ òðàâÿíèñòîé ãàëîôèòíîé ðàñòèòåëüíîñòüþ. Ïîíÿòèå ìàðøà íåîäíîçíà÷íî â ðàçëè÷íûõ ÿçûêàõ è ñòðàíàõ. Â ðóññêîì ÿçûêå ïîä ýòèì òåðìèíîì îáû÷íî ïîäðàçóìåâàþò íèçìåííûå ïîëîñû ìîðñêîãî áåðåãà, ïîäâåðæåííûå âîçäåéñòâèþ âûñîêèõ ïðèëèâîâ èëè íàãîíîâ ìîðñêîé âîäû. TEXT.German: [TAB]Als Marsche bezeichnet man Feuchtgebiete, die eher von niedrigen Blattpflanzen als von Bäumen dominiert werden. Sie entstehen oft an angrenzenden Flüssen oder Seen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]A marsh is a type of wetland that is dominated by herbaceous rather than woody plant species. Marshes can often be found at the edges of lakes and streams, where they form a transition between the aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. They are often dominated by grasses, rushes or reeds. If woody plants are present they tend to be low-growing shrubs. This form of vegetation is what differentiates marshes from other types of wetland such as swamps, which are dominated by trees, and bogs, which are wetlands that have accumulated deposits of acidic peat.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Prairies are ecosystems considered part of the temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands biome by ecologists, based on similar temperate climates, moderate rainfall, and a composition of grasses, herbs, and shrubs, rather than trees, as the dominant vegetation type. Temperate grassland regions include the Pampas of Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay as well as the steppes of Eurasia. Lands typically referred to as "prairie" tend to be in North America. The term encompasses the area referred to as the Interior Lowlands of the United States, Canada and Mexico, which includes all of the Great Plains as well as the wetter, somewhat hillier land to the east. In the U.S., the area is constituted by most or all of the states of North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, and Oklahoma, and sizable parts of the states of Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Texas, Missouri, Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Wisconsin, and western and southern Minnesota. The Central Valley of California is also a prairie. The Canadian Prairies occupy vast areas of Manitoba, Saskatchewan, and Alberta.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A savanna, or savannah, is a grassland ecosystem characterized by the trees being sufficiently widely spaced so that the canopy does not close. The open canopy allows sufficient light to reach the ground to support an unbroken herbaceous layer consisting primarily of grasses. Some classification systems also recognize a grassland savanna from which trees are absent. This article deals only with savanna under the common definition of a grassy woodland with a significant woody plant component. It is often believed that savannas feature widely spaced, scattered trees. However, in many savannas, tree densities are higher and trees are more regularly spaced than in forest. Savannas are also characterized by seasonal water availability, with the majority of rainfall confined to one season. Savannas are associated with several types of biomes. Savannas are frequently in a transitional zone between forest and desert or grassland. Savanna covers approximately 20% of the Earth's land area.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A swamp is a wetland that is forested. Many swamps occur along large rivers, where they are critically dependent upon natural water level fluctuations. Other swamps occur on the shores of large lakes. Some swamps have hammocks, or dry-land protrusions, covered by aquatic vegetation, or vegetation that tolerates periodical inundation. The two main types of swamp are "true" or swamp forests and "transitional" or shrub swamps. In the boreal regions of Canada, the word swamp is colloquially used for what is more correctly termed a bog or muskeg. The water of a swamp may be fresh water, brackish water or seawater. Some of the world's largest swamps are found along major rivers such as the Amazon, the Mississippi, and the Congo. Conservationists have worked hard to preserve swamps. For example, the swamps in Northwest Indiana have been preserved as part of the Indiana Dunes.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Polar Ice[COLOR_REVERT] is impassible terrain to all units. The only option you have is to sail around it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ice is water frozen into the solid state. Usually ice is the phase known as ice Ih, which is the most abundant of the varying solid phases on the Earth's surface. It can appear transparent or opaque bluish-white color, depending on the presence of impurities or air inclusions. The addition of other materials such as soil may further alter the appearance.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Jungles[COLOR_REVERT] grow on tropical latitudes, and your colonists can harvest [LINK=YIELD_COCOA_FRUITS]Cocoa Pods[\LINK] from it, as well as [LINK=YIELD_VALUABLE_WOOD]Valuable Wood[\LINK]. Regular [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Lumber[\LINK] is also provided by Jungles.[NEWLINE]Unlike Forests, a little [LINK=YIELD_FOOD]Food[\LINK] can be grown on Jungles by [LINK=PROFESSION_FARMER]Farmers[\LINK], if the underlying terrain is capable of producing at least 3 Food. [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Lodges[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Lumbermills[\LINK] and [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COCOA_PLANTATION]Cocoa Plantations[\LINK] can be built in Jungles, building any other improvements will remove the Jungle.[NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pioneers[\LINK] can plant Jungles on both [LINK=TERRAIN_MARSH]Marsh[\LINK] and [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savannah[\LINK] Terrain.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Jungle or Tropical forest refers to the dense, more or less impenetrable tropical rainforest biome with an abundance of animal and plant life. The term jungle is technically a synonym to Tropical Rainforest. The word jungle originates from the Sanskrit word jangala which referred to uncultivated land. Although the Sanskrit word refers to "dry land", it has been suggested that an Anglo-Indian interpretation led to its connotation as a dense "tangled thicket". while others have argued that a cognate word in Urdu did refer to forests. The term is prevalent in many languages of South Asia, and Iranian plateau, particularly in Bangla, Hindi, Marathi, Urdu, Punjabi and Persian.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Îïèñàíèå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Äæóíãëè[COLOR_REVERT] ðàñòóò â òðîïè÷åñêèõ øèðîòàõ. Âàøè êîëîíèñòû ìîãóò äîáûâàòü [LINK=YIELD_COCOA_FRUITS]Êàêàî-áîáû[\LINK] â äæóíãëÿõ, òàêæå êàê è [LINK=YIELD_VALUABLE_WOOD]Öåííóþ äðåâåñèíó[\LINK]. Ïîñòîÿííûé [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Ñòðîåâîé ëåñ[\LINK] òàêæå îáåñïå÷åí Äæóíãëÿìè.[NEWLINE]Â îòëè÷èå îò Ëåñà, â Äæóíãëÿõ ìîæåò áûòü âûðàùåíî íåìíîãî [LINK=YIELD_FOOD]Ïèùè[\LINK] ñ ïîìîùüþ [LINK=PROFESSION_FARMER]Ôåðìåðîâ[\LINK], ïðè óñëîâèè ÷òî ëåæàùèé â îñíîâå ëàíäøàôò ñïîñîáñòâóåò ïðîèçâîäñòâó ïî êðàéíåé ìåðå 3-õ åäèíèö Ïèùè. [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Õèæèíû[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Ëåñîïèëêè[\LINK] è [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COCOA_PLANTATION]Ïëàíòàöèè Êàêàî[\LINK] ìîãóò áûòü ïîñòðîåíû â Äæóíãëÿõ, ïîñòðîéêà êàêèõ-ëèáî äðóãèõ óëó÷øåíèé óäàëèò äàííûå Äæóíãëè.[NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Ïåðâîïðîõîäöû[\LINK] ìîãóò ïîñàäèòü Äæóíãëè êàê íà ìåñòíîñòè [LINK=TERRAIN_MARSH]Ìàðøåé[\LINK] è [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Ñàâàíí[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ñïðàâî÷íàÿ èíôîðìàöèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Äæóíãëè èëè òðîïè÷åñêèé ëåñ îòíîñèòñÿ ê ãóñòîìó, áîëåå èëè ìåíåå íåïðîõîäèìîìó âëàæíîìó òðîïè÷åñêîìó ëåñó, áèîìó ñ èçîáèëèåì æèâîòíîé è ðàñòèòåëüíîé æèçíüþ. Äàííûé òåðìèí ''äæóíãëè'' ÿâëÿåòñÿ ôîðìàëüíî ñèíîíèìîì âëàæíîãî òðîïè÷åñêîãî ëåñà. Ñëîâî ''äæóíãëè'' ïðîèñõîäèò îò ñàíñêðèòñêîãî ñëîâà ''jangala'', êîòîðîå îáîçíà÷àåò íåâîçäåëàííóþ çåìëþ. Íåñìîòðÿ íà òî, ÷òî äàííîå ñàíñêðèòñêîå ñëîâî îáîçíà÷àåò ''ñóõàÿ çåìëÿ'', îíî ïðåäïîëàãàåò, ÷òî àíãëî-èíäèéñêîå òîëêîâàíèå âåäåò ê åãî ïîäòåêñòó êàê ãóñòàÿ ''çàïóòàííàÿ ÷àùà''. Â òî âðåìÿ êàê äðóãèå ñîãëàñèëèñü, ÷òî ñëîâî îáùåãî ïðîèñõîæäåíèÿ â ÿçûêå Óðäó îòíîñèëîñü ê ëåñó. Äàííûé òåðìèí ÿâëÿåòñÿ ïðåîáëàäàþùèì â áîëüøèíñòâå ÿçûêîâ Þæíîé Àçèè, à òàêæå Èðàíñêîãî ïëàòî, â ÷àñòíîñòè â ÿçûêàõ Áàíãëà, Õèíäè, Ìàðàòõè, Óðäó, Ïàíäæàáè è Ïåðñèäñêîì ÿçûêå.
TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Dschungel[COLOR_REVERT] wächst in tropischen Breitengraden. Die Kolonien können dort [LINK=YIELD_COCOA_FRUITS]Kakaofrüchte[\LINK] ernten, aber auch [LINK=YIELD_VALUABLE_WOOD]Edelholz[\LINK] schlagen. Normalse [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Holz[\LINK] ist im Dschungel natürlich ebenfalls vorhanden. [NEWLINE]Im Gegensatz zu anderen Wäldern, kann im Dschungel auch [LINK=YIELD_FOOD]Nahrung[\LINK] geerntet werden, wenn das zugrunde liegende Gelände mindestens 3 Nahrung erzeugt. Im Dschungel können [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Holzfällerhütten[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Sägemühlen[\LINK] und [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COCOA_PLANTATION]Kakaoplantagen gebaut werden[\LINK]. Der Bau einer anderen Geländeverbesserung entfernt den Dschungel.[NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pioniere[\LINK] können in [LINK=TERRAIN_MARSH]Sümpfen[\LINK] and [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savannen[\LINK] neuen Dschungel anpflanzen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Dschungel oder Tropischer Wald bezieht sich aufgrund seiner Dichte auf einen mehr oder weniger undurchdringlichen Regenwald mit einer Vielzahl von Pflanzen und Tieren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Jungle or Tropical forest refers to the dense, more or less impenetrable tropical rainforest biome with an abundance of animal and plant life. The term jungle is technically a synonym to Tropical Rainforest. The word jungle originates from the Sanskrit word jangala which referred to uncultivated land. Although the Sanskrit word refers to "dry land", it has been suggested that an Anglo-Indian interpretation led to its connotation as a dense "tangled thicket". while others have argued that a cognate word in Urdu did refer to forests. The term is prevalent in many languages of South Asia, and Iranian plateau, particularly in Bangla, Hindi, Marathi, Urdu, Punjabi and Persian.

The term is prevalent in many languages of South Asia, and Iranian plateau, particularly in Bangla, Hindi, Marathi, Urdu, Punjabi and Persian.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In geography, an oasis (plural: oases) or cienega (Southwestern United States) is an isolated area of vegetation in a desert, typically surrounding a spring or similar water source. Oases also provide habitat for animals and even humans if the area is big enough. The location of oases has been of critical importance for trade and transportation routes in desert areas. Caravans must travel via oases so that supplies of water and food can be replenished. Thus, political or military control of an oasis has in many cases meant control of trade on a particular route. For example, the oases of Awjila, Ghadames and Kufra, situated in modern-day Libya, have at various times been vital to both North-South and East-West trade in the Sahara. The word oasis came into English via Greek oasis, borrowed directly from Egyptian or Demotic. It was not borrowed from Coptic, as is sometimes suggested; the Greek word is attested several centuries before Coptic existed as a written language.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Unter einer Oase versteht man eine isolierte Gegend mit Wasser und Vegetation, die von sehr trockenem Gebiet oder gar Wüste umschlossen ist. Sie stellen in diesen Gebieten Inseln des Lebens dar.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A floodplain, or flood plain, is a flat or nearly flat land adjacent to a stream or river that stretches from the banks of its channel to the base of the enclosing valley walls and experiences flooding during periods of high discharge. It includes the floodway, which consists of the stream channel and adjacent areas that carry flood flows, and the flood fringe, which are areas covered by the flood, but which do not experience a strong current.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Forests[COLOR_REVERT] grow in intermediate and high latitudes, and also on higher terrain in low latitudes. Your colonists can harvest [LINK=YIELD_FUR]Fur[\LINK] and [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Lumber[\LINK] from it.[NEWLINE]Forests prevents the winning of any other resources from its plot other than [LINK=YIELD_ORE]Ore[\LINK], unless a Bonus Resource is present.[LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Lodges[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Lumbermills[\LINK] and [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_TRAPPER_HUT]Trapper Huts[\LINK] can be built in Forests, building any other improvements will remove the Forest.[NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pioneers[\LINK] can plant Forests on both [LINK=TERRAIN_GRASS]Grass[\LINK] and [LINK=TERRAIN_PLAINS]Prairie[\LINK] Terrain.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]A forest, also referred to as a wood or the woods and less often as a "wold" (or "weald"), "holt", or "frith" (or "firth"), is an area with a high density of trees. There are many definitions for forest, based on the various criteria. These plant communities cover approximately 9.4% of the Earth's surface (or 30% of total land area), though they once covered much more (about 50% of total land area), in many different regions and function as habitats for organisms, hydrologic flow modulators, and soil conservers, constituting one of the most important aspects of the Earth's biosphere. Although a forest is classified primarily by trees a forest ecosystem is defined intrinsically with additional species such as fungi.

Ïîíÿòèå ''ëåñ'' ìîæíî ðàññìàòðèâàòü íà ðàçíûõ óðîâíÿõ. Â ãëîáàëüíîì ìàñøòàáå - ýòî ÷àñòü áèîñôåðû, â ëîêàëüíîì - ýòî ìîæåò áûòü íàñàæäåíèå. Ëåñ åùå ìîæíî ðàññìàòðèâàòü êàê ïðèðîäíî-çîíàëüíîå ïîäðàçäåëåíèå, êàê ïðîâèíöèàëüíîå ïîäðàçäåëåíèå, êàê ëåñíîé ìàññèâ (Øèïîâ ëåñ, Øàòèëîâ ëåñ, ×åðíûé ëåñ), êàê ýêîñèñòåìó. Ëåñà çàíèìàþò îêîëî òðåòè ïëîùàäè ñóøè, ïëîùàäü ëåñà íà Çåìëå ñîñòàâëÿåò 38 ìëí êì?. Èç íèõ 264 ìëí ãà, èëè 7 %, ïîñàæåíû ÷åëîâåêîì, ê íà÷àëó XXI âåêà ÷åëîâåê óíè÷òîæèë îêîëî 50 % ïëîùàäåé ëåñîâ, ðàíåå ñóùåñòâîâàâøèõ íà ïëàíåòå. Ïîëîâèíà ëåñíîé çîíû ïðèíàäëåæèò òðîïè÷åñêèì ëåñàì. Ïëîùàäè, çàíÿòûå äåðåâüÿìè ñ ñîìêíóòîñòüþ êðîí ìåíåå 0,2-0,3, ñ÷èòàþòñÿ ðåäêîëåñüåì.
TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Wald[COLOR_REVERT] wächst in gemässigten und nördlichen Breitengraden, aber auch in höheren Lagen der niedrigen Breitengrade. Die Kolonisten können dort [LINK=YIELD_FUR]Pelze[\LINK] gewinnen und [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Holz[\LINK] schlagen. Zur Gewinnung anderer Rohstoffe, ist Wald sehr schlecht geeignet. Es können [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Holzfällerhütten[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Sägemühlen[\LINK] und [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_TRAPPER_HUT]Jagdhütten[\LINK] in Wäldern gebaut werden. Andere Geländeverbesserungen entfernen den Wald. [NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pioniere[\LINK] können neue Wälder auf [LINK=TERRAIN_GRASS]Grasland[\LINK] and [LINK=TERRAIN_PLAINS]Prairie[\LINK] pflanzen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Unter einem Wald versteht man ein Gebiet mit stark ausgeprägtem Baumbewuchs verschiendensten Alters. Die Dichte und die Baumarten und Pflanzenarten variieren von Region zu Region.

These plant communities cover approximately 9.4% of the Earth's surface (or 30% of total land area), though they once covered much more (about 50% of total land area), in many different regions and function as habitats for organisms, hydrologic flow modulators, and soil conservers, constituting one of the most important aspects of the Earth's biosphere. Although a forest is classified primarily by trees a forest ecosystem is defined intrinsically with additional species such as fungi.

Í. Êðûëîâ, êîòîðûé îïðåäåëèë òàéãó êàê òåìíîõâîéíûé áîðåàëüíûé ñîìêíóòûé ëåñ è ïðîòèâîïîñòàâèë åå ñîñíîâîìó áîðó, ëèñòâåííè÷íûì, ñîñíîâûì è ìåëêîëèñòâåííûì ëåñàì.
TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Taiga[COLOR_REVERT] wächst in nördlichen Breitengraden, aber auch gelegentlich in höheren Lagen der gemässigten Breitengrade. Die Kolonisten können dort [LINK=YIELD_FUR]Pelze[\LINK] oder [LINK=YIELD_PREMIUM_FUR]Hochwertige Pelze[\LINK] gewinnen und [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Holz[\LINK] schlagen. Zur Gewinnung anderer Rohstoffe, ist Taiga sehr schlecht geeignet. Es können [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Holzfällerhütten[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Sägemühlen[\LINK] und [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_TRAPPER_HUT]Jagdhütten[\LINK] in der Taiga gebaut werden. Andere Geländeverbesserungen entfernen den Wald. [NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pioniere[\LINK] können neue Wälder auf [LINK=TERRAIN_GRASS]Tundra[\LINK] pflanzen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Unter einem Wald versteht man ein Gebiet mit stark ausgeprägtem Baumbewuchs verschiendensten Alters. Die Dichte und die Baumarten und Pflanzenarten variieren von Region zu Region.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]A forest, also referred to as a wood or the woods and less often as a "wold" (or "weald"), "holt", or "frith" (or "firth"), is an area with a high density of trees. There are many definitions for forest, based on the various criteria. These plant communities cover approximately 9.4% of the Earth's surface (or 30% of total land area), though they once covered much more (about 50% of total land area), in many different regions and function as habitats for organisms, hydrologic flow modulators, and soil conservers, constituting one of the most important aspects of the Earth's biosphere. Although a forest is classified primarily by trees a forest ecosystem is defined intrinsically with additional species such as fungi.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Light Forests[COLOR_REVERT] can grow on all latitudes. They slightly increase the production of [LINK=YIELD_FUR]Fur[\LINK] and [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Lumber[\LINK] from its plot, but it also retains all other yields the plot generates as a result of its base terrain, albeit in reduced numbers.[NEWLINE][LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Lodges[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Lumbermills[\LINK] and [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_TRAPPER_HUT]Trapper Huts[\LINK] can be built in Light Forests, building any other improvements will remove the Forest.[NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pioneers[\LINK] cannot plant Light Forests anywhere. Once they're gone, they're gone for ever.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]A forest, also referred to as a wood or the woods and less often as a "wold" (or "weald"), "holt", or "frith" (or "firth"), is an area with a high density of trees. There are many definitions for forest, based on the various criteria. These plant communities cover approximately 9.4% of the Earth's surface (or 30% of total land area), though they once covered much more (about 50% of total land area), in many different regions and function as habitats for organisms, hydrologic flow modulators, and soil conservers, constituting one of the most important aspects of the Earth's biosphere. Although a forest is classified primarily by trees a forest ecosystem is defined intrinsically with additional species such as fungi.

Îíè íåçíà÷èòåëüíî óâåëè÷èâàþò ïðîèçâîäñòâî [LINK=YIELD_FUR]Ìåõà[\LINK] è [LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Ñòðîèòåëüíîãî Ëåñà[\LINK] íà äàííîé êëåòêå, îäíàêî îíè òàêæå ñîäåðæàò âñå îñòàëüíîå ñûðüå ýòîé êëåòêè, êîòîðîå îáðàçóåòñÿ â ðåçóëüòàòå ãåíåðàöèè îñíîâíîãî ëàíäøàôòà, õîòÿ åãî êîëè÷åñòâî óìåíüøåíî.[NEWLINE][LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Õèæèíû[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Ëåñîïèëêè[\LINK] è [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_TRAPPER_HUT]Îõîòíè÷üè Äîìèêè[\LINK] ìîãóò áûòü ïîñòðîåíû â Ðåäêîëåñüÿõ, ïîñòðîéêà êàêèõ-ëèáî äðóãèõ óëó÷øåíèé óäàëèò Ëåñ.[NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Ïåðâîïðîõîäöû[\LINK] íå ìîãóò ñàäèòü ãäå-ëèáî Ðåäêîëåñüÿ. Âñòðå÷àþòñÿ â ïðèãðàíè÷íûõ îáëàñòÿõ ïóñòûíü è ïîëóïóñòûíü âî âñåõ ÷àñòÿõ ñâåòà, íàïðèìåð, â Àôðèêå, Þæíîé Àìåðèêå è Àâñòðàëèè ðåäêîñòîéíûå, ÷àñòî íèçêîðîñëûå ëåñà, îáðàçîâàííûå ñóõèìè è êîëþ÷èìè äðåâåñíûìè ðàñòåíèÿìè, òàêæå ìîãóò íàçûâàòü ðåäêîëåñüåì.
TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Buschland[COLOR_REVERT] und lichte Wälder wachsen in allen Breitengraden. Die Kolonisten können dort ein wenig [LINK=YIELD_FUR]Felle[\LINK] gewinnen und auch etwas[LINK=YIELD_LUMBER]Holz[\LINK] schlagen. Die Gewinnung anderer Rohstoffe wird durch Buschland nur leicht behindert. Es können [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LODGE]Holzfällerhütten[\LINK], [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LUMBERMILL]Sägemühlen[\LINK] und [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_TRAPPER_HUT]Jagdhütten[\LINK] im Buschland gebaut werden. Andere Geländeverbesserungen entfernen den Wald. [NEWLINE][LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pioniere[\LINK] können kein neues Buschland pflanzen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Unter einem Wald versteht man ein Gebiet mit stark ausgeprägtem Baumbewuchs verschiendensten Alters. Die Dichte und die Baumarten und Pflanzenarten variieren von Region zu Region.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Storms[COLOR_REVERT] take many movement point to sail through, and on top of that damage your ships as well. As such, you'll usually want to evade these weather systems. They occur only on [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Ocean[\LINK] tiles, so on [LINK=TERRAIN_COAST]Coast[\LINK] or [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Fresh Water Lake[COLOR_REVERT] tiles you'll be safe from them.[NEWLINE]Storms can never destroy a ship, but they can severely weaken it. For more information, see [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Winds and Storms[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]A storm is any disturbed state of an astronomical body's atmosphere especially affecting its surface, and strongly implying severe weather. It may be marked by strong wind, hail, thunder and/or lightning (a thunderstorm), heavy precipitation (snowstorm, rainstorm), heavy freezing rain (ice storm), strong winds (tropical cyclone, windstorm), or wind transporting some substance through the atmosphere as in a dust storm, blizzard, sandstorm, etc. Storms generally lead to negative impacts to lives and property such as storm surge, heavy rain or snow (causing flooding or road impassibility), lightning, wildfires, and vertical wind shear; however, systems with significant rainfall can alleviate drought in places they move through. Heavy snowfall can allow special recreational activities to take place which would not be possible otherwise, such as skiing and snowmobiling.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Îïèñàíèå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Øòîðìû[COLOR_REVERT] áåðóò ìíîãî î÷êîâ ïåðåäâèæåíèÿ çà ïðîïëûâàíèå ÷åðåç íèõ è ê òîìó æå ïîâðåæäàþò âàøè êîðàáëè. Ïî ñóùåñòâó, âû áóäåòå îáû÷íî õîòåòü èçáåæàòü ýòè ïîãîäíûå ñèñòåìû. Îíè âîçíèêàþò òîëüêî íà êëåòêàõ [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Îêåàíà[\LINK], ïîýòîìó íà êëåòêàõ [LINK=TERRAIN_COAST]Ïîáåðåæüÿ[\LINK] èëè [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ïðåñíîâîäíûõ Îçåð[COLOR_REVERT] âû áóäåòå íàõîäèòüñÿ â áåçîïàñíîñòè îò íèõ.[NEWLINE]Øòîðìû íèêîãäà íå ìîãóò óíè÷òîæèòü êîðàáëü, íî îíè ìîãóò ñåðüåçíî îñëàáèòü åãî. Äëÿ äîïîëíèòåëüíîé èíôîðìàöèè, ñìîòðèòå [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Âåòðû è Øòîðìû[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ñïðàâî÷íàÿ èíôîðìàöèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Øòîðì - ýòî ëþáîå íàðóøåííîå ñîñòîÿíèå àñòðîíîìè÷åñêèõ òåë àòìîñôåðû, ãëàâíûì îáðàçîì âëèÿþùèå íà åå ïîâåðõíîñòü è ñèëüíî âëèÿþùóþ ñóðîâóþ ïîãîäó. Îí ìîæåò áûòü îòìå÷åí ñèëüíûì âåòðîì, ãðàäîì, ãðîìîì è/èëè ìîëíèåé (ãðîçà), îáèëüíûìè îñàäêàìè (ñíåæíàÿ áóðÿ, ëèâåíü), îáèëüíûì ëåäÿíûì äîæäåì (ëåäÿíîé øòîðì), ñèëüíûìè âåòðàìè (òðîïè÷åñêèé öèêëîí, óðàãàí), ëèáî âåòåðîì, ïåðåíîñÿùèì íåêîòîðûå âåùåñòâà ÷åðåç àòìîñôåðó êàê â ïûëüíîé áóðå, ìåòåëè, ïåñ÷àíîé áóðå, è ò.ä. Øòîðìû â îáùåì ñëó÷àå âåäóò ê íåãàòèâíûìì âëèÿíèÿì â æèçíåäåÿòåëüíîñòè è â îñîáåííîñòè òàêèå êàê øòîðìîâîé íàãîí (ïðèëèâ), ëèâåíü èëè ñíåãîïàä (âûçûâàÿ íàâîäíåíèå èëè äîðîæíóþ íåïðîõîäèìîñòü), ìîëíèÿ, ëåñíûå ïîæàðû è âåðòèêàëüíûé ñäâèã âåòðà. Îäíàêî, ìåòåîðîëîãè÷åñêèå óñëîâèÿ ñ çíà÷èòåëüíûìè àòìîñôåðíûìè îñàäêàìè ìîãóò ñìÿã÷èòü çàñóõó â ìåñòàõ, ãäå îíè ïðîõîäÿò.
TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Stürme[COLOR_REVERT] benötigen viele Bewegungspunkte um hindurch zu segeln und beschädigen auch die Schiffe darin. Daher sollten Stürme wenn möglich vermieden werden. Sie kommen nur auf dem offenen [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Ozean[\LINK] vor. Daher sind [LINK=TERRAIN_COAST]Küsten[\LINK] für die Schiffe viel sicherer.[NEWLINE]Stürme zerstören Schiffe nicht vollständig, können diese aber schwer anschlagen. Für weitere Informationen siehe [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Wind und Stürme[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintegrund[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ein Sturm ist ein gestörter Zustand der Atmosphäre, der heftige Wetterbedingungen verursacht. Dazu können sehr starke Winde, Regen, Schnee, Hagel, Donner und Blitze gehören.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]A storm is any disturbed state of an astronomical body's atmosphere especially affecting its surface, and strongly implying severe weather. It may be marked by strong wind, hail, thunder and/or lightning (a thunderstorm), heavy precipitation (snowstorm, rainstorm), heavy freezing rain (ice storm), strong winds (tropical cyclone, windstorm), or wind transporting some substance through the atmosphere as in a dust storm, blizzard, sandstorm, etc. Storms generally lead to negative impacts to lives and property such as storm surge, heavy rain or snow (causing flooding or road impassibility), lightning, wildfires, and vertical wind shear; however, systems with significant rainfall can alleviate drought in places they move through. Heavy snowfall can allow special recreational activities to take place which would not be possible otherwise, such as skiing and snowmobiling.

Heavy snowfall can allow special recreational activities to take place which would not be possible otherwise, such as skiing and snowmobiling.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Favourable Winds[COLOR_REVERT] impose a Defensive Penalty of any ships who found themselves inside, but they allow vessels with the [LINK=PROMOTION_SEA_EXPLORER]Sea Explorer[\LINK] promotion to move at double speed. The Defensive Penalty can be reduced by the [LINK=PROMOTION_MOBILITY1]Mobility I[\LINK] promotions.[NEWLINE] Like other weather systems, Favourable Winds occur only on [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Ocean[\LINK] tiles, not on [LINK=TERRAIN_COAST]Coast[\LINK] or [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Fresh Water Lake[COLOR_REVERT] tiles.[NEWLINE]For more information, see [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Winds and Storms[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1](navigation) A wind which aids a craft in making progress in a desired direction; usually used in plural form and chiefly in connection with sailing vessels. Also known as fair wind.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Îïèñàíèå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Áëàãîïðèÿòíûå Âåòðû[COLOR_REVERT] íàêëàäûâàþò Øòðàô ê Çàùèòå ëþáîìó êîðàáëþ, êîòîðûé íàõîäèòñÿ âíóòðè íèõ, îäíàêî îíè ïîçâîëÿþò ñóäíàì ñ ïîâûøåíèåì [LINK=PROMOTION_SEA_EXPLORER]Ìîðñêîé Èññëåäîâàòåëü[\LINK] äâèãàòüñÿ ñ óäâîåííîé ñêîðîñòüþ. Øòðàô ê Çàùèòå ìîæåò áûòü ñíÿò ïîâûøåíèåì [LINK=PROMOTION_MOBILITY1]Ìîáèëüíîñòü I[\LINK].[NEWLINE] Ïîäîáíî äðóãèì ïîãîäíûì ñèñòåìàì, Áëàãîïðèÿòíûå Âåòðû âîçíèêàþò òîëüêî íà êëåòêàõ [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Îêåàíà[\LINK] , íå íà êëåòêàõ [LINK=TERRAIN_COAST]Ïîáåðåæüÿ[\LINK] èëè [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ïðåñíîâîäíûõ Îçåð [COLOR_REVERT].[NEWLINE]Äëÿ äîïîëíèòåëüíîé èíôîðìàöèè, ñìîòðèòå [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Âåòðû è Øòîðìû[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ñïðàâî÷íàÿ èíôîðìàöèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1](íàâèãàöèÿ) Âåòåð, êîòîðûé óâåëè÷èâàåò õîä ñóäíà â íóæíîì íàïðàâëåíèè; îáû÷íî èñïîëüçóåòñÿ â ôîðìå ìíîæåñòâåííîãî ÷èñëà è ãëàâíûì îáðàçîì â îòíîøåíèè ïàðóñíûõ ñóäîâ. Òàêæå èçâåñòåí êàê ïîïóòíûé âåòåð.
TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Günstige Winde[COLOR_REVERT] erlauben es Schiffen mit der Beförderung [LINK=PROMOTION_SEA_EXPLORER]Entdecker der Meere[\LINK] mit doppelter Geschwindigkeit zu segeln. Allerdings senken sie auch die Verteidigungswerte des darin befindlichen Schiffes. Dieser Effekt kann aber durch die Beförderung [LINK=PROMOTION_MOBILITY1]Mobilität I[\LINK] gesenkt werden. Günstige Winde kommen nur auf dem offenen [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Ozean[\LINK] vor. Für weitere Informationen siehe [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Wind und Stürme[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintegrund[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1] Wind der das Vorankommen eines Segelschiffs in einer bestimmten Richtung begünstigt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB](navigation) A wind which aids a craft in making progress in a desired direction; usually used in plural form and chiefly in connection with sailing vessels. Also known as fair wind.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB](navigation) A wind which aids a craft in making progress in a desired direction; usually used in plural form and chiefly in connection with sailing vessels. Also known as fair wind.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Unfavourable Winds[COLOR_REVERT] grant a Defensive Bonus to all ships inside, but they require more movement points to sail through. This movement penalty can be reduced by the [LINK=PROMOTION_MOBILITY1]Mobility I[\LINK] and [LINK=PROMOTION_SAILING3]Naval Warfare III[\LINK] promotions.[NEWLINE] Like other weather systems, Unfavourable Winds occur only on [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Ocean[\LINK] tiles, not on [LINK=TERRAIN_COAST]Coast[\LINK] or [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Fresh Water Lake[COLOR_REVERT] tiles.[NEWLINE]For more information, see [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Winds and Storms[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1](navigation) Winds which delay the progress of a craft in a desired direction; used chiefly in connection with sailing vessels.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Îïèñàíèå[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Íåáëàãîïðèÿòíûå Âåòðû[COLOR_REVERT] ãàðàíòèðóþò Çàùèòíûé Áîíóñ âñåì êîðàáëÿì, ðàñïîëîæåííûì âíóòðè êëåòêè, îäíàêî îíè òðåáóþò áîëüøå î÷êîâ ïåðåäâèæåíèÿ äëÿ ïðîïëûâàíèÿ. Ýòîò øòðàô çà ïåðåäâèæåíèå ìîæåò áûòü ñíÿò ñ ïîìîùüþ ïîâûøåíèé [LINK=PROMOTION_MOBILITY1]Ìîáèëüíîñòü I[\LINK] è [LINK=PROMOTION_SAILING3]Âîéíà íà Ìîðå III[\LINK].[NEWLINE] Ïîäîáíî äðóãèì ïîãîäíûì ñèñòåìàì, Íåáëàãîïðèÿòíûå Âåòðû âîçíèêàþò òîëüêî íà êëåòêàõ [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Îêåàíà[\LINK], íå íà êëåòêàõ [LINK=TERRAIN_COAST]Ïîáåðåæüÿ[\LINK] èëè êëåòêàõ [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ïðåñíîâîäíûõ Îçåð[COLOR_REVERT].[NEWLINE]Äëÿ äîïîëíèòåëüíîé èíôîðìàöèè, ñìîòðèòå [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Âåòðû è Øòîðìû[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ñïðàâî÷íàÿ èíôîðìàöèÿ[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1](íàâèãàöèÿ) Âåòðû, êîòîðûå çàäåðæèâàþò õîä ñóäíà â íóæíîì íàïðàâëåíèè; èñïîëüçóåòñÿ ãëàâíûì îáðàçîì â îòíîøåíèè ïàðóñíûõ ñóäîâ.
TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ungünstige Winde[COLOR_REVERT] geben den darin befindlichen Schiffen zwar kleine Vorteile bei der Verteidigung, erfordern aber mehr Bewegungspunkte um darin zu segeln. Dieser Effekt kann aber durch die Beförderungen [LINK=PROMOTION_MOBILITY1]Mobilität I[\LINK] und [LINK=PROMOTION_SAILING3]Seekrieg III[\LINK] gesenkt werden. Ungünstige Winde kommen nur auf dem offenen [LINK=TERRAIN_COEAN]Ozean[\LINK] vor. Für weitere Informationen siehe [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Wind und Stürme[\LINK][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintegrund[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Wind der das Vorankommen eines Segelschiffs in einer bestimmten Richtung behindert.
